s.text: In Easy Riders, Raging Bulls , Peter Biskind chronicles how Beatty parlayed the heartthrob status he'd won from 1961's Splendor in the Grass into a controlling position as a producer.
In the '70s, he bullied screenwriters and directors into making Shampoo and Heaven Can Wait his way.
According to Brownstein, Beatty led the polls in the 1974 race to succeed Reagan as California governor but refused to run.

According to Brownstein, Beatty led the polls in the 1974 race to succeed Reagan as California governor but refused to run.
He doesn't really want to run, but perhaps he can use the threat of a candidacy to make himself a behind-the-scenes player, the guy who delivers the left to Al Gore or Bill Bradley.
And in 1976 Beatty resisted pleas to make a late primary challenge to Jimmy Carter.
He didn't speak to reporters from the late '70s till the early '90s.
In interviews, Beatty repeatedly chokes when asked for specific political ideas.
Beatty can forbid interviews, decline to answer questions, and refuse to appear in public.
